--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Shane Mingins" <shane.mingins@...> wrote:
> =

> Or do you see Agitator complementing JUnit in the same way whether
you a=
re
> using TTD or not?
> 
> My current thinking is the two tools solve slig=
htly different
problems ...
> or they address testing is different ways.
..=
.
> Anyhow at the moment I am thinking that developers should
> start with =
JUnit or JUnit + Agitator and not simply just Agitator.
> 
> Your thoughts?=

> 

Hi Shane,

I'm not Alberto but I'll give you my take on it.  Short ans=
wer is I
think Agitator & JUnit are complementary TDD or no. (I'll leave it=
 to
someone else to make the point that of course you should use TDD.  I
ag=
ree with them, but that isn't your question.)

Longer answer is that when y=
ou use JUnit TDD there are (at least) two
different kinds of value you get,=
 design and correctness. It is the
correctness aspect that Robert Martin is=
 talking about when he
compares TDD to double entry bookkeeping. It answers=
 the question
"does my algorithm work? does input a combined with input b g=
ive me
exactly output c?" JUnit tests give you this kind of confidence.

Ag=
itator is more about limits and bounds and did your algorithm, which
you al=
ready know works correctly on the happy path, unexpectedly blow
up in some =
cases. Or leave the object in an illegal state? Or return a
non-sensical va=
lue? or... Agitation is also good for "does input of
category A with input =
of category B always give me output of category
C?" If I were looking for a=
 word to compare to correctness I'd
probably have to choose robustness.

So=
 would I recommend JUnit + Agitator over just simply Agitator?  Heck
yeah! =
and I've already done so many times on (both in person and on my
blog) alre=
ady.  :)

Jtf
